<target_code>
Here is the code of send_all:
```c
static size_t
send_all (MHD_socket sock, const unsigned char *buf, size_t len)
{
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t off;

  for (off = 0; off < len; off += (size_t) ret)
  {
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
    ret = send (sock, (const void *) &buf[off], len - off, 0);
#else  /* Native W32 */
    ret = send (sock, (const void *) &buf[off], (int) (len - off), 0);
#endif /* Native W32 */
    if (0 > ret)
    {
      if (EAGAIN == errno)
      {
        ret = 0;
        continue;
      }
      break;
    }
    if (0 == ret)
    {
      break;
    }
  }
  return off;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: No suspicious fragments found for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. The only pointer in the function is the parameter 'const unsigned char *buf', which is already const-qualified. The expression '&buf[off]' yields a 'const unsigned char *' and the code casts it to 'const void *', preserving the const qualification (the cast is redundant but does not remove const). There are no other pointer variables, no assignments or casts that convert away const-qualification, and the platform-specific cast of the length to 'int' does not involve pointers. Therefore there are no places in this function that appear to violate or require investigation for Rule 8.13.
